summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Texas today announced criminal charges against a Houston man accused of orchestrating a triple-murder of two fellow gang members.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Houston, alleges that, on June 20, 2012, Davion Griffin, a member of the street gang the Forum Park Crips, was shot and killed in the parking lot of a southwest Houston nightclub.  According to the complaint, Griffin was present at the nightclub when the shooting occurred, but did not participate in the planning or execution of the murders.  Griffin also allegedly used a cell phone to record conversations with other members of the group, including one in which Griffin allegedly told one of the gang members that he would "chop it up" with them if the opportunity presented itself.  In a parallel action, the United States District Court for the Central District of New York today entered a final judgment against Griffin, ordering him to pay a civil penalty of $25,000.  Without admitting or denying the SEC's allegations, Griffin consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933, Section 10(b) the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders him to disgorge his ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, pay a $10,000 civil penalty, and appoint a receiver for the receiver of the receiver.  On August 2, 2013, the Honorable Judge Timothy J. McCole granted the SEC’s request for a temporary restraining order against Griffin and ordered him to return to the district court for a hearing scheduled for September 19, 2013.  McCole agreed to a preliminary injunction, which prohibits him from participating in the issuance, purchase, offer, or sale of any firearm, and to pay an officer-and-director bar.  He also agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.  McCluskey agreed to settle the SEC case by consenting to a permanent injunction against further violations of Section 15(a)(1) and 16(b)(2) of The Securities Act and Rule 15b2-1 thereunder and to a conduct-based injunction prohibiting him from associating with anyone with a criminal history.  McCluskey also agreed not to cooperate with the SEC in its investigation of the matter.  Finally, the court found that Griffin was not liable for the imposition of a civil injunctive relief and ordered the receiver to pay disgorgement of $5,000, which is equal to the amount of
